equations.equation: \overrightarrow{F_{12}} = \frac{kq_{1}q_{2}}{r^2}\hat{r}\\\mbox{Where }\overrightarrow{F_{12}}\mbox{ is the force }q_{1}\mbox{ exerts on }q_{2}\\\hat{r}\mbox{ is the normal of the direction between the charges.}
\mbox{The net charge in a closed system is constant.}
\mbox{The superposition principle entends for electric forces as well meaning}\\\mbox{the net force is the sum of the independent individual electrical forces.}
\mbox{The electric field at any point is the force per unit charge that a charge would experience at that point.}\\\overrightarrow{E}=\frac{\overrightarrow{F}}{q} = \frac{kq_{source}}{r^{2}}\hat{r}
p=qd\\\mbox{Where } d \mbox{ is the distance between the two charges making up the dipole.}
\overrightarrow{E}=\int{d\overrightarrow{E}}=\int{\frac{k\ dq}{r^{2}}\hat{r}}
\overrightarrow{E}=-\frac{kp}{y^{3}}\hat{i}\\\mbox{ When } y \gg \mbox{ dipole charge distance.}
\overrightarrow{E}=\frac{2kp}{x^{3}}\hat{i}\\\mbox{ When } x \gg \mbox{ dipole charge distance.}

equations.header: Torque on a dipole in an electric field
equations.equation: \overrightarrow{\tau} = \overrightarrow{p} \times \overrightarrow{E} = qdE\sin(\theta)

equations.header: Potential energy for a dipole in an electric field
equations.equation: U = -\overrightarrow{p}\cdot\overrightarrow{E}
\mbox{A material in which charges are not free to move around.}
\mbox{Insulating materials that when an electric field is applied, the contained molecules polarize creating dipoles.}
\mbox{A material with charges that can move freely throughout the material.}

\Phi = \overrightarrow{E} \cdot \overrightarrow{A} = EA\cos(\theta)\\\Phi = \int^{}_{surface}{\overrightarrow{E} \cdot d\overrightarrow{A}}\\\mbox{Where } \overrightarrow{A} \mbox{ is the outward pointing normal to the surface and has the magnitude of the surface's area.}
\Phi = \oint{\overrightarrow{E} \cdot d\overrightarrow{A}} = \frac{q_{enclosed}}{\epsilon_{0}}\\\mbox{Where the charge must be enclosed inside the closed surface.}

\mbox{The electric field is zero inside a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium.}\\\mbox{Any net charge must be on the conductor's surface.}\\\mbox{Also see note "Electric Field for a surface of a conductor in Electrostatic Equilibrium"}

equations.header: Electric Field for a surface of a conductor in Electrostatic Equilibrium (365)
equations.equation: E=\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}}\\\mbox{Where }\sigma \mbox{ is the surface charge density.}\\\mbox{E is perpendicular to the surface of the conductor}
\mbox{Outside: }E = \frac{kQ}{r^2}\\\mbox{Inside: }E = \frac{kQr}{r_{sphere}^3}\\\mbox{Inside hollow: }E = 0

\mbox{The line must be assumed infinite in length.}\\\mbox{This works well when we are checking the field close to the line and not near the edges.}\\\mbox{Outside: }E = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\mbox{ (}\lambda\mbox{ Is the charge density in }C/m\mbox{)}\\\mbox{Inside hollow: }E = 0
\mbox{Outside: }E=\frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}\mbox{ (}\sigma\mbox{ Is the charge density in } C/m^2 \mbox{)}
\mbox{Electric potential energy is the potential energy the charge in question has that is gained by an electric field.}

\mbox{Electric potential difference is the potential energy per unit charge in moving some from A to B.}\\\mbox{Positive means more electric potential energy for a positive charge moving from A to B, negative means less.}\\\Delta V_{AB} = \frac{\Delta U_{AB}}{q} = -\int^{B}_{A}{\overrightarrow{E} \cdot d \overrightarrow{r}}

equations.header: Electric Potential Difference from a charged Point
equations.equation: \Delta V_{AB} = kq(\frac{1}{r_B} - \frac{1}{r_A})\\\mbox{Where } r_A \mbox{ and } r_B \mbox{ are the distances from the charge to A and B respectively.}
\mbox{The resulting Electic Potential can be calculated from the sum of the independent individual electric potentials.}
\mbox{A point used as a implicit reference to find differences in potential.}\\\mbox{When someone says find the potential of a point they mean with respect to the zero of potential.}
\mbox{The zero of potential is usually defined to be infinitely away from our point of interest, in that case.}\\V = \frac{kq}{r}
\mbox{The zero of potential is infinitely away from our sphere.}\\V = \frac{kq}{r}

\mbox{Where the zero of potential is infinitely away from our point of interest}\\\mbox{and that point's distance from the dipole is much larger than the dipole's length.}\\V = \frac{kp\cos{\theta}}{r^2}\\\mbox{Where }p = qd \mbox{ and } \theta \mbox{ is measured from (or at least near) the center of the dipole to the point with respect to the dipole amathcal{E}s.}
\mbox{Using the Potential of a point charge note,}\\\mbox{we can find the potential made by a more complex shape as a bunch of point charge potentials, giving.}\\V = \int{\frac{k\ dq}{r}}
\mbox{Two points are equipotentials to each other if their is no electric potential difference between them.}
\overrightarrow{E} = -(\frac{\delta V}{\delta x}\hat{i} + \frac{\delta V}{\delta y}\hat{j} + \frac{\delta V}{\delta z}\hat{k})
C = \frac{Q}{V} \mbox{ (} V \mbox{ is electrical potential difference between the plates)}\\\mbox{The capacitance unit is the Farad.}

\mbox{In the equation, } C = \frac{Q}{V}\mbox{ an insulating dielectric can weaken the electric field making } V \mbox{ smaller and thus } C \mbox{ bigger.}\\\mbox{This factor varies with the material and is called the dielectric constant } \kappa \mbox{.}
C = \kappa \frac{\epsilon_0 A}{d} \mbox{(} d \mbox{ is the distance beween the plates)}
U=\frac{1}{2}CV^2

equations.header: Potential Energy (U) for a Parallel-Plate capacitor
equations.equation: U=\frac{Q^2d}{2\epsilon_0 A}
\mbox{The working voltage is the mamathcal{E}mum safe potential difference that when pushed past may cause dielectric breakdown.}
\mbox{See page 393 if instructions unclear.}\\C_{total} = C_1 + C_2 + ...

equations.header: Capacitance for a series of capacitors
equations.equation: \mbox{See page 393/394 if instructions unclear.}\\\frac{1}{C_{total}} = \frac{1}{C_1} + \frac{1}{C_2} + ...\\\mbox{For two capacitors you can say, } C_{total} = \frac{C_1 C_2}{C_1 + C_2}
\mbox{Parallel capacitors have the same voltage.}

equations.header: Property of a series of capacitors
equations.equation: \mbox{A series of capacitors have the same charge.}
u_E = \frac{1}{2}\epsilon_0 E^2\\\mbox{Only works if E is constant.}\\\mbox{Multiply this with the volume of the object to get the energy stored.}
U = \frac{1}{2}\epsilon_0\int{E^2 dV}

\mbox{Current is in the direction that positive charges flow,}\\\mbox{if only negative charges are moving then the current's direction is opposite the flow.}\\I = \frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta t} (A)\mbox{, } I = \frac{dQ}{dt} (A)\\\mbox{Where } \Delta Q \mbox{ or } dQ \mbox{ is the charge crossing a given area over } \Delta t \mbox{ or } dt

I = n*A*q*v_d\\n\mbox{ is the number of charges per unit volume.}\\A \mbox{ is the cross-sectional area of the conductor.}\\q \mbox{ is the charge of each charge.}\\v_d \mbox{ is the drift speed of a charge.}
R = \frac{\rho L}{A}\mbox{ (} L \mbox{ is length, } A \mbox{ is the cross-sectional area)}
\overrightarrow{J} = \frac{\overrightarrow{I}}{A} = nq\overrightarrow{v_d}

\overrightarrow{J} = \sigma \overrightarrow{E}\mbox{ ( } \sigma \mbox{ is a conductor's conductivity)}\\\overrightarrow{J} = \frac{\overrightarrow{E}}{\rho}\mbox{(} \rho \mbox{ is a conductor's resistivity)}\\\rho \mbox{ is the reciprocal of } \sigma \mbox{ and has unit ohm (}\Omega \mbox{).}
I=\frac{V}{R} \mbox{ (} R \mbox{ is an object's resistance, not resistivity)}

\mbox{A material used in meditation.}\\\mbox{A material in which it's conductivity (}\sigma \mbox{) is independent of the electric field.}\\\mbox{This means that }\overrightarrow{J} \mbox{ in Ohm's Law is linearly proportional to }\overrightarrow{E}

\mbox{A material not used in meditation.}\\\mbox{A material in which it's conductivity (}\sigma \mbox{) changes with the electric field.}\\\mbox{This means that }\overrightarrow{J} \mbox{ in Ohm's Law is not linearly proportional to }\overrightarrow{E}

equations.header: A metal's resistivity and it's temperature (pg 407)
equations.equation: \mbox{Resistivity is almost linear with the temperature.}
\mbox{The power (in watts) from an electric current turned into other forms of energy.}\\P = IV \implies P = I^2 R\implies P = \frac{V^2}{R}

\mbox{Ignore the force part of the name, it's seems like a misnomer.}\\\mbox{EMF is the potential voltage difference between a source like a battery.}\\\mbox{It is measured in volts and a capital cursive E is used to denote it: }\mathcal{E}
\mbox{Nothing new, but it's used throughout this chapter.}\\I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R}\mbox{ (}\mathcal{E} \mbox{ is the voltage of the battery)}
\frac{1}{R_{total}} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + ...\\\mbox{For two resistors you can say, }R_{total} = \frac{R_1 R_2}{R_1 + R_2}

\mbox{1. The sum of voltage changes in a closed circuit is zero.}\\\mbox{2. The sum of currents at any node is zero (A node is a point where 3+ wires meet).}\\\mbox{Example 25.4 is great, notice } I_2 \mbox{ is backwards, direction doesn't matter (it gets fixed by the sign).}
\mbox{Measures the voltage across two points.}\\\mbox{Must be placed parallel to the circuit, an ideal voltmeter has infinite resistance.}
\mbox{Measures the current flowing through itself.}\\\mbox{Must be placed in series to the circuit, an ideal ammeter has no resistance.}
\mbox{Measures the resistance.}\\\mbox{You can use an ammeter with a known voltage to the same effect.}
\mbox{Does what a voltmeter, ammeter, and ohmmeter all do.}\\\mbox{This is like the triforce of electrical instruments.}
\mbox{RC stands for resistor capacitor.}\\\mbox{A battery connected to a capacitor with a resistor somewhere and a switch.}
I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R}e^{-\frac{t}{RC}}
V_C = \mathcal{E} (1 - e^{-\frac{t}{RC}})
I = \frac{V_0}{R}e^{-\frac{t}{RC}}\mbox{ (} V_0 \mbox{ is the capacitor's initial voltage)}
V = V_0 e^{-\frac{t}{RC}} \mbox{ (} V_0 \mbox{ is the capacitor's initial voltage)}
\mbox{The phenomena of magnetism involve moving electric charge.}

\mbox{Thus far, it's never really mentioned explicitly in this book but this is what I could gather from wikipedia.}\\\mbox{The permeability is related to a material's ability to create and support magnetic fields within itself.}
\mbox{If you point your thumb in the direction of the current,}\\\mbox{your other fingers curl in the magnetic field's direction.}

\overrightarrow{F_B} = q\overrightarrow{v} \times \overrightarrow{B}\\q \mbox{ is the charge's charge.}\\\overrightarrow{v} \mbox{ is the velocity of the charge.}\\\overrightarrow{B}\mbox{ is the magnetic field and has unit Tesla (T).}

equations.header: Particle moving perpendicularly to a uniform magnetic field (pg 442)
equations.equation: \mbox{The partical experiences uniform circular motion.}\\r = \frac{mv}{qB}

equations.header: Period and frequency of particle in a uniform magnetic field (pg 442)
equations.equation: T = \frac{2\pi m}{qB}\implies f = \frac{qB}{2\pi m}\\f \mbox{ is called the cyclotron frequency.}
\overrightarrow{F} = I\overrightarrow{l} \times \overrightarrow{B}\\\overrightarrow{l} \mbox{ has magnitude equal to the wire's length and direction of the current.}

\overrightarrow{F_B} = q\overrightarrow{v} \times \overrightarrow{B}\\q \mbox{ is the charge's charge.}\\\overrightarrow{v} \mbox{ is the velocity of the charge.}\\\overrightarrow{B}\mbox{ is the magnetic field and has unit Tesla (T).}

\mbox{Pronounced like Bee-O Sav-var.}\\\overrightarrow{B} = \frac{\mu_0}{4\pi}\int{\frac{I d\overrightarrow{l} \times \hat{r}}{r^2}}\\\mu_0 \mbox{ is the permeability constant.}\\d\overrightarrow{l} \mbox{ is the vector along the current.}\\\hat{r} \mbox{ is the unit vector from the source to the point where we are evaluating the field.}

equations.header: Magnetic field of infinitely long wire
equations.equation: \mbox{See page 447-448 for deriviation (it's really good practice).}\\B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi y}
\overrightarrow{\mu} = NI\overrightarrow{A}\\N \mbox{ is how many current loops there are.}\\\overrightarrow{A} \mbox{ is the loop area pointing perpendicular to the loop.}

equations.header: Magnetic Field for Dipole on dipole amathcal{E}s (pg 449)
equations.equation: B = \frac{\mu_0}{2\pi} \frac{\mu}{x^3} \mbox{(}\mu\mbox{ is the magnetic dipole moment)}
\mbox{This is kinda implicit but it's nice if you forget.}\\\Phi_B=\int{\overrightarrow{B} \cdot d\overrightarrow{A}}\mbox{ (} d\overrightarrow{A} \mbox{ is the normal of the surface)}

\mbox{Neat law, first off all magnetic fields are closed loops.}\\\mbox{From this we can say that the magnetic flux emerging from any } \textbf{closed}\mbox{ surface is zero.}\\\Phi_B =\oint{\overrightarrow{B} \cdot d\overrightarrow{A}} = 0 \mbox{ (} d\overrightarrow{A} \mbox{ is the normal of the surface)}
\overrightarrow{\tau} = \overrightarrow{\mu} \times \overrightarrow{B}

equations.header: Potential energy for a Magnetic Dipole (pg 450)
equations.equation: U = -\overrightarrow{\mu} \cdot \overrightarrow{B}

\mbox{The book goes way more in depth by the way.}\\\mbox{Magnetism caused by a group of atoms (called a magnetic domain) with magnetic moments all aligned the same direction.}\\\mbox{You can achieve this effect by applying an external magnetic field to the metal causing the atoms to align with the field.}\\\mbox{If the material is still magnetic after the magnetic field is removed, the material is a hard ferromagnet. It is a soft ferromagnet otherwise.}

equations.header: Ampere's Law for steady current (or really slow ones) (pg 454-455)
equations.equation: \oint{\overrightarrow{B} \cdot d\overrightarrow{r}} = \mu_0 I_{encircled}\mbox{ (} d\overrightarrow{r} \mbox{ runs along the surface of the enclosing object)}\\\mbox{Note if }\oint{\overrightarrow{B} \cdot d\overrightarrow{r}} \neq 0 \mbox{ then } I_{encircled} \mbox{ must be non-zero.}

\mbox{A tightly wound coil with current going through it.}\\\mbox{In a perfect solenoid, the outside the magnetic field is zero.}\\\mbox{In a perfect solenoid, the inside magnetic field is constant: }\\B = \mu_0nI\mbox{ (}n \mbox{ is how many loops there are per unit length)}
B = \mu_0nI\mbox{ (}n \mbox{ is how many loops there are per unit length)}
\Phi_B = BA = \mu_0 nI\pi R^2

equations.header: Mechanical Power supplied to pull loop (pg 472-473)
equations.equation: \mbox{You really should check the book on this one.}\\P = \frac{B^2 l^2 v^2}{R}\\l\mbox{ is the length of the side perpendicular to v.}
\mbox{The direction of an induced emf's or current's magnetic field}\\\mbox{will oppose the change in the magnetic flux of the creator.}

equations.header: Faraday's law of induction for circuits (pg 472)
equations.equation: \mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi_B}{dt}\\\mathcal{E} \mbox{ is the induced EMF for a} \textbf{ circuit}\mbox{.}

\mbox{A conductive material moving in a magnetic field will create a large induced current and thus a large loss of power.}\\\mbox{What this does is makes it very hard to move it in or out of a magnetic field, essentially sapping kinetic energy.}
\mbox{Inductance is changing the magnetic flux by way of changing the current of the source}\\\mbox{which in turn would change the magnetic field it produces and thus the magnetic flux.}
\mbox{Take two coils next to each other, a changing current in one of the coils causes an induced emf in the other one.}
\mbox{An ironic property of inductance.}\\\mbox{Self inductance is when a circuit's own magnetic field opposes it's own change.}\\\mbox{This makes it harder to change the current in a circuit.}
\mbox{A device used to help cause self-inductance by creating a more concentrated magnetic flux.}\\\mbox{An ideal inductor would have zero resistance.}

\mbox{A device used to help cause self-inductance by creating a more concentrated magnetic flux.}\\\mbox{An ideal inductor would have zero resistance.}\\\mbox{In circuit diagrams, they are drawn as multiple loop-the-loops.}
L = \frac{\Phi}{I} (H)\\\Phi \mbox{ is the magnetic flux through the inductor.}\\I \mbox{ is the current through the inductor.}

equations.header: Faraday's law of induction for inductors (pg 477)
equations.equation: \mathcal{E}_L = -L \frac{dI}{dt}\\\mbox{The inductor's emf opposes the change in current as expected.}\\\mbox{Because of this, it's sometimes called the }\textbf{back emf}\mbox{.}
\mbox{RL stands for Resistor-Inductor (Since L is used for inductors)}\\I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} (1 - e^{-\frac{Rt}{L}}) \mbox{ (} \mathcal{E} \mbox{ is the voltage of the source)}
P = LI \frac{dI}{dt}
U = \frac{1}{2} L I^2
u_B = \frac{B^2}{2\mu_0}

\mbox{A changing magnetic field always creates an induced electric field.}\\\mbox{The electric field then creates the induced current } \textbf{if}\mbox{ there is a circuit.}\\\mbox{These electric fields are usually closed loops which means they're nonconservative.}

\mbox{This is the most general form and applies to any changing magnetic field.}\\\oint_{loop}{E \cdot d\overrightarrow{r}} = -\frac{d\Phi_B}{dt}\\d\overrightarrow{r} \mbox{ runs along the loop of the lefthand integral.}\\\overrightarrow{E}\mbox{ is the induced electric field (see note on induced electric fields).}\\\Phi_B \mbox{ is the magnetic flux of any open surface contained in the loop.}

\mbox{All materials are diamagnetic to some extent.}\\\mbox{Diamagnetism is the phenomena of when you apply a magnetic field to it,}\\\mbox{it creates an induced magnetic field and gets repelled from the original magnetic field.}\\\mbox{It's best to just read the small page on it.}
V = V_p\sin(\omega t + \phi_v)\\I = I_p\sin(\omega t + \phi_I)

equations.header: Peak value and RMS relation for a sine wave (pg 491)
equations.equation: \mbox{The peak value for a sine wave is related to the RMS:}\\a_{peak} = \sqrt{2} \cdot a_{rms}
I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{V_p}{R}\sin(\omega t + \phi)
I = \omega CV_p \sin(\omega t + \frac{\pi}{2})\\I_p = \omega C V_p = \frac{V_p}{1 / {\omega C}} = \frac{V_p}{X_C}
X_C = \frac{1}{\omega C} (\Omega)
I = \frac{V_p}{\omega L}\sin(\omega t - \frac{\pi}{2})\\I_P = \frac{V_P}{\omega L} = \frac{V_P}{X_L}
X_L = \omega L (\Omega)

\mbox{A vector representing the phase and amplitude in AC circuits.}\\\mbox{A phasor is a vector rotating counterclockwise with the angular frequency and whose length is the amplitude.}\\\mbox{Taking the y component of the phasor gives you V(t) or I(t) at that moment.}

\mbox{A LC Circuit stands for Inductor-Capacitor circuit and is similar to the mass-spring system,}\\\mbox{oscillating from potential energy to kinetic energy, back and forth.}\\\mbox{Since this is ideal, the total energy (}U \mbox{) is constant thus } \frac{dU}{dt} = 0 \mbox{, from this we can say:}\\q = q_P \cos(\omega t)\mbox{, and, }\omega = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}
\mbox{A RLC Circuit stands for Resistor-Inductor-Capacitor circuit.}\\q(t) = q_P \cdot e^{-\frac{Rt}{2L}}\cos(\omega t)
\mbox{Connecting an AC generator to the circuit, the}\\\mbox{resonant frequency for the generator is: } \omega = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}
V_P = \sqrt{V_{RP}^2 + (V_{LP} - V_{CP})^2}\\I_P = \frac{V_P}{\sqrt{R^2 + (X_L - X_C)^2}} = \frac{V_P}{Z}
\mbox{A measure of resistance including the effects of capacitance and inductance.}\\Z = \sqrt{R^2 + (X_L - X_C)^2} (\Omega)

\tan(\phi) = \frac{X_L - X_C}{R}\\\mbox{ Where } \phi = \phi_V - \phi_I \mbox{ and is the phase difference between voltage and current.}\\\mbox{A positive }\phi \mbox{ means voltage leads current, negative means current leads voltage.}

\langle P \rangle = I_{rms} V_{rms} \cos(\phi)\\\mbox{Where }\langle \rangle \mbox{ mean time average over one cycle.}\\\mbox{Thus } \langle P \rangle \mbox{ is the average power over one cycle.}\\\cos(\phi) \mbox{ is called the }\textbf{power factor}\mbox{.}

\mbox{Transformers consist of two wires wrapped opposite of another usually around a magnetic core.}\\\mbox{One of the coils will have an AC current going through it, that one is the primary.}\\\mbox{Using the power of induced emf the primary will create a current in the other one, known as the secondary.}\\\mbox{A step-up transformer increases the voltage from primary to secondary, a step-down transformer does the opposite.}\\\mbox{In circuit diagrams they are drawn as two parallel multiple loop-the-loops with two also parallel bars in the middle.}\\\mbox{Also they're robots in disguise.}
V_{secondary} = \frac{N_{secondary}}{N_{primary}}V_{primary}\\N\mbox{ is the amount of coil turns}
\mbox{Johnny Bravo!}
\mbox{It's defined as the charge of a single electron or proton.}\\e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} C
\mbox{The one used in say, Coulombs Law.}\\k = 9.0\times10^{9}\frac{N*m^{2}}{C^{2}}
\mbox{I really don't want to write all these out. Check page 393.}
\mbox{I'm not going to write these down, check out page 406.}
\mbox{The measure of permeability inside a vacuum.}\\\mu_0 = 4\pi \times 10^{-7} \frac{N}{A^2}
Hz = \frac{cycle}{s}
C = 6.25\times10^{18} \cdot e
\overrightarrow{E} = \frac{N}{C} =\frac{V}{m}
\frac{kg}{m/s^2}
N \cdot m
\frac{J}{C}
\mbox{One Elementary Charge times one Volt}\\eV = 1.6 \times 10^{-19}J
F=\frac{C}{V}
A=\frac{C}{s}
\Omega = \frac{V}{A}
T = \frac{N \cdot s}{C \cdot m}
G = 10^{-4} \cdot T
H = \frac{T \cdot m^2}{A}
a = \frac{v^{2}}{r}
\omega = 2\pi f
p = mv
f = \frac{1}{T}
